docs.title: SQL Databases (Relational)
docs.text:
Structured data with predefined schemas and relationships:

  • PostgreSQL - Advanced features, JSON support
  • MySQL - Fast, reliable, widely supported

docs.title: NoSQL Databases
docs.text:
Flexible schemas for evolving data structures:

  • MongoDB - Document-oriented database

docs.title: Use PostgreSQL When:
docs.text:
• You need advanced SQL features
  • JSON support is required
  • ACID compliance is critical
  • Complex queries and joins are common

docs.title: Use MySQL When:
docs.text:
• You need a simple, fast database
  • Building web applications
  • Read-heavy workloads
  • Wide hosting support needed

docs.title: Use MongoDB When:
docs.text:
• Schema flexibility is important
  • Working with JSON-like documents
  • Horizontal scaling is required
  • Rapid development with changing requirements

docs.title: Databases
docs.text: A comprehensive guide to working with databases, focusing on MongoDB, PostgreSQL, and MySQL.

docs.title: SQL Databases (Relational)
docs.text:
• PostgreSQL: Advanced open-source relational database
  • MySQL: Popular open-source relational database

docs.title: NoSQL Databases
docs.text: • MongoDB: Document-oriented database

docs.title: Use PostgreSQL When:
docs.text:
• You need complex queries and joins
  • ACID compliance is critical
  • You need advanced features (JSON support, full-text search)
  • Data integrity is paramount

docs.title: Use MySQL When:
docs.text:
• You need a simple, fast relational database
  • You're building a web application
  • You want wide hosting support
  • Read-heavy operations are common

docs.title: Use MongoDB When:
docs.text:
• You have flexible, evolving schemas
  • You're working with JSON-like documents
  • Horizontal scaling is important
  • You need high write throughput

docs.title: PostgreSQL (Node.js with pg)
docs.text:
const { Pool } = require("pg");

const pool = new Pool({
  user: "username",
  host: "localhost",
  database: "mydb",
  password: "password",
  port: 5432,
});

// Query
const result = await pool.query("SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = $1", [1]);

docs.title: Connection Pooling
docs.text:
Always use connection pooling for better performance:

// PostgreSQL
const pool = new Pool({ max: 20 });

// MySQL
const pool = mysql.createPool({ connectionLimit: 10 });

// MongoDB
const client = new MongoClient(uri, { maxPoolSize: 10 });

docs.title: Indexing
docs.text:
Create indexes on frequently queried fields:

-- PostgreSQL/MySQL
CREATE INDEX idx_user_email ON users(email);

// MongoDB
await users.createIndex({ email: 1 });

docs.title: PostgreSQL/MySQL
docs.text:
const connection = await pool.getConnection();
await connection.beginTransaction();

try {
  await connection.query("INSERT INTO users ...");
  await connection.query("INSERT INTO orders ...");
  await connection.commit();
} catch (error) {
  await connection.rollback();
  throw error;
}

docs.title: MongoDB
docs.text:
const session = client.startSession();
session.startTransaction();

try {
  await users.insertOne({ name: "John" }, { session });
  await orders.insertOne({ userId: 1 }, { session });
  await session.commitTransaction();
} catch (error) {
  await session.abortTransaction();
  throw error;
}

docs.title: SQL Injection Prevention
docs.text:
❌ Bad (SQL Injection vulnerable):

const query = `SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = '${email}'`;

✅ Good (Using parameterized queries):

const query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = $1";
const result = await pool.query(query, [email]);

docs.title: MongoDB Injection Prevention
docs.text:
❌ Bad:

await users.findOne({ email: req.body.email });

✅ Good (Validate input):

const { email } = req.body;
if (typeof email !== "string") throw new Error("Invalid input");
await users.findOne({ email });

docs.title: Using MongoDB Driver (Node.js)
docs.text:
const { MongoClient } = require('mongodb');

const uri = 'mongodb://admin:password@localhost:27017';
const client = new MongoClient(uri);

async function connect() {
  await client.connect();
  const db = client.db('mydatabase');
  return db;

const mongoose = require('mongoose');

await mongoose.connect('mongodb://admin:password@localhost:27017/mydatabase');

docs.title: Create Documents
docs.text:
const users = db.collection('users');

// Insert one
await users.insertOne({
  name: 'John Doe',
  email: 'john@example.com',
  age: 30
});

// Insert many
await users.insertMany([
  { name: 'Jane Doe', email: 'jane@example.com', age: 25 },
  { name: 'Bob Smith', email: 'bob@example.com', age: 35 }
]);

docs.title: Read Documents
docs.text:
// Find one
const user = await users.findOne({ email: 'john@example.com' });

// Find many
const allUsers = await users.find({}).toArray();

// Find with filter
const adults = await users.find({ age: { $gte: 18 } }).toArray();

// Find with projection (select specific fields)
const names = await users.find({}, { projection: { name: 1, _id: 0 } }).toArray();

docs.title: Update Documents
docs.text:
// Update one
await users.updateOne(
  { email: 'john@example.com' },
  { $set: { age: 31 } }
);

// Update many
await users.updateMany(
  { age: { $lt: 18 } },
  { $set: { isMinor: true } }
);

// Upsert (update or insert)
await users.updateOne(
  { email: 'new@example.com' },
  { $set: { name: 'New User' } },
  { upsert: true }
);

docs.title: Delete Documents
docs.text:
// Delete one
await users.deleteOne({ email: 'john@example.com' });

// Delete many
await users.deleteMany({ age: { $lt: 18 } });

docs.title: Comparison Operators
docs.text:
// Equal
{ age: 30 }

// Greater than
{ age: { $gt: 18 } }

// Greater than or equal
{ age: { $gte: 18 } }

// Less than
{ age: { $lt: 65 } }

// In array
{ status: { $in: ['active', 'pending'] } }

// Not equal
{ status: { $ne: 'inactive' } }

docs.text:

// OR

// NOT

docs.title: Aggregation Pipeline
docs.text:
const results = await users.aggregate([
  // Stage 1: Match documents
  { $match: { age: { $gte: 18 } } },

  // Stage 2: Group by field
  { $group: {
    _id: '$country',
    averageAge: { $avg: '$age' },
    count: { $sum: 1 }
  }},

  // Stage 3: Sort results
  { $sort: { count: -1 } },

  // Stage 4: Limit results
  { $limit: 10 }
]).toArray();

docs.title: Mongoose Schema
docs.text:
const mongoose = require('mongoose');

const userSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  name: {
    type: String,
    required: true,
    trim: true
  },
  email: {
    type: String,
    required: true,
    unique: true,
    lowercase: true
  },
  age: {
    type: Number,
    min: 0,
    max: 120
  },
  role: {
    type: String,
    enum: ['user', 'admin', 'moderator'],
    default: 'user'
  },
  createdAt: {
    type: Date,
    default: Date.now
  }
});

const User = mongoose.model('User', userSchema);

// Usage
const user = new User({
  name: 'John Doe',
  email: 'john@example.com',
  age: 30
});

await user.save();

docs.title: Transactions
docs.text:
const session = client.startSession();

try {
  await session.withTransaction(async () => {
    await users.insertOne({ name: 'John' }, { session });
    await orders.insertOne({ userId: 1, amount: 100 }, { session });
  });
} finally {
  await session.endSession();
}

docs.title: Connection Management
docs.text:
// Create client once and reuse
let cachedClient = null;

async function connectToDatabase() {
  if (cachedClient) {
    return cachedClient;
  }

  const client = await MongoClient.connect(uri, {
    maxPoolSize: 10
  });

  cachedClient = client;
  return client;
}

docs.title: Schema Design
docs.text:
• Embed related data that is accessed together
  • Use references for data that is accessed independently
  • Avoid deep nesting (keep it under 3-4 levels)
  • Use arrays for one-to-few relationships
  • Use references for one-to-many or many-to-many

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
// Use projection to limit returned fields
await users.findOne({ _id: 1 }, { projection: { name: 1, email: 1 } });

// Use lean() with Mongoose for faster queries
await User.find({}).lean();

// Create indexes on frequently queried fields
await users.createIndex({ email: 1 });

docs.title: Create Table
docs.text:
CREATE TABLE users (
  id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
  name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
  email VARCHAR(255) UNIQUE NOT NULL,
  age INT CHECK (age >= 0),
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);

docs.title: Insert Data
docs.text:
-- Insert single row
INSERT INTO users (name, email, age)
VALUES ('John Doe', 'john@example.com', 30);

-- Insert multiple rows
INSERT INTO users (name, email, age)
VALUES 
  ('Jane Doe', 'jane@example.com', 25),
  ('Bob Smith', 'bob@example.com', 35);

-- Insert and get ID
INSERT INTO users (name, email, age)
VALUES ('Alice', 'alice@example.com', 28);
SELECT LAST_INSERT_ID();

docs.title: Select Data
docs.text:
-- Select all
SELECT * FROM users;

-- Select specific columns
SELECT name, email FROM users;

-- Where clause
SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > 25;

-- Order by
SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY age DESC;

-- Limit and offset
SELECT * FROM users LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20;

-- Aggregate functions
SELECT COUNT(*), AVG(age), MAX(age) FROM users;

docs.title: Update Data
docs.text:
-- Update single row
UPDATE users 
SET age = 31 
WHERE email = 'john@example.com';

-- Update multiple rows
UPDATE users 
SET age = age + 1 
WHERE age < 30;

docs.title: Delete Data
docs.text:
-- Delete specific rows
DELETE FROM users WHERE age < 18;

-- Delete all rows
DELETE FROM users;

-- Truncate (faster, resets auto-increment)
TRUNCATE TABLE users;

docs.title: Joins
docs.text:
-- Inner join
SELECT u.name, o.amount
FROM users u
INNER JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id;

-- Left join
SELECT u.name, o.amount
FROM users u
LEFT JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id;

-- Right join
SELECT u.name, o.amount
FROM users u
RIGHT JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id;

docs.title: Subqueries
docs.text:
-- Subquery in WHERE
SELECT * FROM users 
WHERE id IN (SELECT user_id FROM orders WHERE amount > 100);

-- Subquery in FROM
SELECT avg_age FROM (
  SELECT AVG(age) as avg_age FROM users
) AS subquery;

docs.title: Group By
docs.text:
SELECT country, COUNT(*) as user_count, AVG(age) as avg_age
FROM users
GROUP BY country
HAVING COUNT(*) > 10
ORDER BY user_count DESC;

docs.title: JSON Support (MySQL 5.7+)
docs.text:
-- Create table with JSON column
CREATE TABLE products (
  id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
  name VARCHAR(100),
  attributes JSON
);

-- Insert JSON data
INSERT INTO products (name, attributes)
VALUES ('Laptop', '{"brand": "Dell", "specs": {"ram": "16GB", "cpu": "i7"}}');

-- Query JSON data
SELECT * FROM products 
WHERE JSON_EXTRACT(attributes, '$.brand') = 'Dell';

-- Shorter syntax
SELECT * FROM products 
WHERE attributes->>'$.brand' = 'Dell';

-- Update JSON field
UPDATE products 
SET attributes = JSON_SET(attributes, '$.specs.ram', '32GB')
WHERE id = 1;

docs.title: Indexes
docs.text:

-- Unique index

docs.title: Transactions
docs.text:
START TRANSACTION;

INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ('John', 'john@example.com');
UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance - 100 WHERE user_id = 1;
UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance + 100 WHERE user_id = 2;

COMMIT;
-- or ROLLBACK; if something goes wrong

docs.title: Using mysql2 in Node.js
docs.text:
const connection = await pool.getConnection();

try {
  await connection.beginTransaction();

  await connection.execute('INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES (?, ?)', ['John', 'john@example.com']);
  await connection.execute('UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance - ? WHERE user_id = ?', [100, 1]);
  await connection.execute('UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance + ? WHERE user_id = ?', [100, 2]);

  await connection.commit();
} catch (error) {
  await connection.rollback();
  throw error;
} finally {
  connection.release();
}

docs.title: Parameterized Queries
docs.text:
❌ Bad (SQL Injection vulnerable):

const query = `SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = '${email}'`;

✅ Good: 

const email = req.body.email;
const [rows] = await pool.execute('SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = ?', [email]);

const limit = 10;
const offset = (page - 1) * limit;

docs.title: Foreign Keys

CREATE TABLE orders (
  id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
  user_id INT NOT NULL,
  amount DECIMAL(10, 2) CHECK (amount > 0),
  status ENUM('pending', 'completed', 'cancelled') DEFAULT 'pending',
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
  FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE
);

  ('Bob Smith', 'bob@example.com', 35);

-- Insert and return
INSERT INTO users (name, email, age)
VALUES ('Alice', 'alice@example.com', 28)
RETURNING id, name;

docs.title: Select Data
docs.text:
-- Select all
SELECT * FROM users;

-- Select specific columns
SELECT name, email FROM users;

-- Where clause
SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > 25;

-- Order by
SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY age DESC;

-- Limit and offset
SELECT * FROM users LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20;

-- Aggregate functions
SELECT COUNT(*), AVG(age), MAX(age) FROM users;

docs.title: Update Data
docs.text:
-- Update single row
UPDATE users 
SET age = 31 
WHERE email = 'john@example.com';

-- Update multiple rows
UPDATE users 
SET age = age + 1 
WHERE age < 30;

-- Update and return
UPDATE users 
SET name = 'John Smith' 
WHERE id = 1
RETURNING *;

docs.title: Delete Data
docs.text:
-- Delete specific rows
DELETE FROM users WHERE age < 18;

-- Delete all rows
DELETE FROM users;

-- Delete and return
DELETE FROM users WHERE id = 1 RETURNING *;

docs.title: Joins
docs.text:
-- Inner join
SELECT u.name, o.amount
FROM users u
INNER JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id;

-- Left join
SELECT u.name, o.amount
FROM users u
LEFT JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id;

-- Multiple joins
SELECT u.name, o.amount, p.name AS product
FROM users u
INNER JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id
INNER JOIN products p ON o.product_id = p.id;

docs.title: Subqueries
docs.text:
-- Subquery in WHERE
SELECT * FROM users 
WHERE id IN (SELECT user_id FROM orders WHERE amount > 100);

-- Subquery in FROM
SELECT avg_age FROM (
  SELECT AVG(age) as avg_age FROM users
) AS subquery;

docs.title: Group By
docs.text:
SELECT country, COUNT(*) as user_count, AVG(age) as avg_age
FROM users
GROUP BY country
HAVING COUNT(*) > 10
ORDER BY user_count DESC;

docs.title: Window Functions
docs.text:
-- Row number
SELECT name, age, 
  ROW_NUMBER() OVER (ORDER BY age DESC) as rank
FROM users;

-- Running total
SELECT date, amount,
  SUM(amount) OVER (ORDER BY date) as running_total
FROM orders;

docs.title: JSON Support
docs.text:
PostgreSQL has excellent JSON support:

-- Create table with JSON column
CREATE TABLE products (
  id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
  name VARCHAR(100),
  attributes JSONB
);

-- Insert JSON data
INSERT INTO products (name, attributes)
VALUES ('Laptop', '{"brand": "Dell", "specs": {"ram": "16GB", "cpu": "i7"}}');

-- Query JSON data
SELECT * FROM products 
WHERE attributes->>'brand' = 'Dell';

-- Query nested JSON
SELECT * FROM products 
WHERE attributes->'specs'->>'ram' = '16GB';

-- Update JSON field
UPDATE products 
SET attributes = jsonb_set(attributes, '{specs,ram}', '"32GB"')
WHERE id = 1;

docs.title: Indexes
docs.text:
-- Create index
CREATE INDEX idx_users_email ON users(email);

-- Unique index
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX idx_users_email ON users(email);

-- Composite index
CREATE INDEX idx_users_name_age ON users(name, age);

-- Partial index
CREATE INDEX idx_active_users ON users(email) WHERE active = true;

-- GIN index for JSON
CREATE INDEX idx_products_attributes ON products USING GIN (attributes);

-- Full-text search index
CREATE INDEX idx_users_name_fulltext ON users USING GIN (to_tsvector('english', name));

docs.title: Transactions
docs.text:
BEGIN;

INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ('John', 'john@example.com');
UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance - 100 WHERE user_id = 1;
UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance + 100 WHERE user_id = 2;

COMMIT;
-- or ROLLBACK; if something goes wrong

docs.title: Using pg in Node.js
docs.text:
const client = await pool.connect();

try {
  await client.query('BEGIN');

  await client.query('INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ($1, $2)', ['John', 'john@example.com']);
  await client.query('UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance - $1 WHERE user_id = $2', [100, 1]);
  await client.query('UPDATE accounts SET balance = balance + $1 WHERE user_id = $2', [100, 2]);

  await client.query('COMMIT');
} catch (error) {
  await client.query('ROLLBACK');
  throw error;
} finally {
  client.release();
}

docs.title: Parameterized Queries
docs.text:
❌ Bad (SQL Injection vulnerable): 

const email = req.body.email;
const query = `SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = '${email}'`;

✅ Good: 

const email = req.body.email;
const query = 'SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = $1';
const result = await pool.query(query, [email]);

docs.title: Pagination
docs.text:
const page = 1;
const limit = 10;
const offset = (page - 1) * limit;

const result = await pool.query(
  'SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY id LIMIT $1 OFFSET $2',
  [limit, offset]
);

docs.title: Search
docs.text:
const searchTerm = 'john';
const result = await pool.query(
  'SELECT * FROM users WHERE name ILIKE $1',
  [`%${searchTerm}%`]
);

docs.title: Bulk Insert
docs.text:
const users = [
  ['John', 'john@example.com'],
  ['Jane', 'jane@example.com'],
  ['Bob', 'bob@example.com']
];

const query = 'INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ($1, $2)';

for (const user of users) {
  await pool.query(query, user);
}

// Better: Use a single query
const values = users.map((_, i) => `($${i * 2 + 1}, $${i * 2 + 2})`).join(',');
const flatUsers = users.flat();
await pool.query(
  `INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ${values}`,
  flatUsers
);

docs.title: Use Constraints
docs.text:
CREATE TABLE orders (
  id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
  user_id INTEGER NOT NULL REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  amount DECIMAL(10, 2) CHECK (amount > 0),
  status VARCHAR(20) DEFAULT 'pending',
  created_at TIMESTAMP NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW(),
  CONSTRAINT valid_status CHECK (status IN ('pending', 'completed', 'cancelled'))

CREATE TABLE users (

  name VARCHAR(100),

docs.title: SQlite
docs.text:
SQLite is a lightweight, file-based database that stores all data in a single file instead of running as a separate database server.

Think of it as A database you can carry around as a file

Simple explanation

Most databases work like this:

App → Database Server → Data

SQLite works like this:

App → Database File (.db)

No server. No setup. No username/password.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Serverless
docs.text:
• No database service to run

  • No background process

  • Your app directly reads/writes the file

docs.title: 2️⃣ File-based
docs.text:
• Entire database lives in one file (e.g. dev.db)
  • Easy to copy, move, backup, or delete

docs.title: 3️⃣ Zero configuration
docs.text:
• No installation needed
  • Works out of the box
  • Perfect for beginners and local development

docs.title: 4️⃣ Very fast for small apps
docs.text:
Great performance for:

  • Small to medium datasets
  • Single-user or low-concurrency apps

docs.title: Where SQLite is commonly used
docs.text:
1. Mobile apps (Android, iOS)
  2. Desktop apps
  3. Browsers (Chrome, Firefox internally use SQLite)
  4. Local development for web apps
  5. Prototypes & demos

docs.title: docker-compose.yml

version: '3.8'

services:
  # Web application
  app:
    build: .
    container_name: myapp
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    environment:
      - NODE_ENV=production
      - DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@db:5432/mydb
    depends_on:
      - db
      - redis
    volumes:
      - ./logs:/app/logs
    restart: unless-stopped

  # PostgreSQL database
  db:
    image: postgres:15-alpine
    container_name: postgres
    ports:
      - "5432:5432"
    environment:
      - POSTGRES_USER=user
      - POSTGRES_PASSWORD=password
      - POSTGRES_DB=mydb
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    restart: unless-stopped

  # Redis cache
  redis:
    image: redis:7-alpine
    container_name: redis
    ports:
      - "6379:6379"
    volumes:
      - redis_data:/data
    restart: unless-stopped

volumes:
  postgres_data:
  redis_data:

docs.text:
1. Use official base images when possible

  9. Health checks to monitor container health

async function getPosts() {
  const res = await fetch('https://api.example.com/posts');

export default async function Posts() {
  const posts = await getPosts();

  return (
    <div>

'use client'; // Mark as client component

import { useState, useEffect } from 'react';

export default function ClientPosts() {
  const [posts, setPosts] = useState([]);

  useEffect(() => {
    fetch('https://api.example.com/posts')
      .then((res) => res.json())
      .then((data) => setPosts(data));
  }, []);

  return (
    <div>
      {posts.map((post) => (
        <div key={post.id}>{post.title}</div>
      ))}
    </div>
  );
}

  }));
}

docs.title: Middleware
docs.text:
// middleware.js
import { NextResponse } from 'next/server';

export function middleware(request) {
  // Check authentication, redirect, etc.
  const token = request.cookies.get('token');

  if (!token) {
    return NextResponse.redirect(new URL('/login', request.url));
  }

  return NextResponse.next();
}

export const config = {
  matcher: ['/dashboard/:path*', '/profile/:path*'],
};

docs.title: React
docs.text: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces, particularly single-page applications. It allows developers to create reusable UI components.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
# Create a new React app
npx create-react-app my-app
cd my-app
npm start

docs.title: Using Vite (Faster Alternative)
docs.text:
npm create vite@latest my-app -- --template react
cd my-app
npm install
npm run dev

docs.title: Components
docs.text: Components are the building blocks of React applications.

docs.title: Function Components
docs.text:
function Welcome(props) {
  return <h1>Hello, {props.name}</h1>;
}

docs.title: Arrow Function Components
docs.text:
const Welcome = ({ name }) => {
  return <h1>Hello, {name}</h1>;
};

docs.title: JSX
docs.text:
JSX is a syntax extension for JavaScript that looks similar to HTML.

const element = <h1>Hello, world!</h1>;
const user = { firstName: 'John', lastName: 'Doe' };
const greeting = <h1>Hello, {user.firstName}!</h1>;

docs.title: Props
docs.text:
Props (properties) are used to pass data from parent to child components.

function ParentComponent() {
  return <ChildComponent name="John" age={25} />;
}

function ChildComponent({ name, age }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <p>Name: {name}</p>
      <p>Age: {age}</p>
    </div>
  );
}

docs.title: State
docs.text:
State is used to manage data that changes over time within a component.

import { useState } from 'react';

function Counter() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

  return (
    <div>
      <p>Count: {count}</p>
      <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>Increment</button>
    </div>
  );
}

docs.title: useState
docs.text:
Manages component state.

const [state, setState] = useState(initialValue);

docs.title: useEffect
docs.text:
Performs side effects in function components.

import { useEffect } from 'react';

function Example() {
  useEffect(() => {
    // Side effect code here
    document.title = 'Component Mounted';

    // Cleanup function (optional)
    return () => {
      console.log('Component will unmount');
    };
  }, []); // Dependency array
}

docs.title: useContext
docs.text:
Access context values.

import { useContext } from 'react';

const value = useContext(MyContext);

docs.title: useRef
docs.text:
Create a mutable reference that persists across renders.

import { useRef } from 'react';

function TextInput() {
  const inputRef = useRef(null);

  const focusInput = () => {
    inputRef.current.focus();
  };

  return (
    <>
      <input ref={inputRef} type="text" />
      <button onClick={focusInput}>Focus Input</button>
    </>
  );
}

docs.title: useMemo
docs.text:
Memoize expensive calculations.

import { useMemo } from 'react';

const memoizedValue = useMemo(() => computeExpensiveValue(a, b), [a, b]);

docs.title: useCallback
docs.text:
Memoize callback functions.

import { useCallback } from 'react';

const memoizedCallback = useCallback(() => {
  doSomething(a, b);
}, [a, b]);

docs.title: Event Handling
docs.text:
function Button() {
  const handleClick = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    console.log('Button clicked');
  };

  return <button onClick={handleClick}>Click Me</button>;
}

docs.title: Conditional Rendering
docs.text:
function Greeting({ isLoggedIn }) {
  return (
    <div>
      {isLoggedIn ? <h1>Welcome back!</h1> : <h1>Please sign in.</h1>}
    </div>
  );
}

docs.title: Lists and Keys
docs.text:
function List({ items }) {
  return (
    <ul>
      {items.map((item) => (
        <li key={item.id}>{item.name}</li>
      ))}
    </ul>
  );
}

docs.title: Forms
docs.text:
function Form() {
  const [value, setValue] = useState('');

  const handleSubmit = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    console.log('Submitted:', value);
  };

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
      <input
        type="text"
        value={value}
        onChange={(e) => setValue(e.target.value)}
      />
      <button type="submit">Submit</button>
    </form>
  );
}
